Description: Computer software that provides low-level control for the hardware and device(s) of a host, such as BIOS or UEFI/EFI
Changes made to firmware, including its settings and/or data, such as MBR (Master Boot Record) and VBR (Volume Boot Record)
Baseband firmware on the UE does not match authorized version by the OEM or carrier
A profile representing a user, device, service, or application used to authenticate and access resources
An attempt by a user to gain access to a network or computing resource, often by providing credentials (ex: Windows EID 4776 or /var/log/auth.log)
Initial construction of a new account (ex: Windows EID 4720 or /etc/passwd logs)
Removal of an account (ex: Windows EID 4726 or /var/log access/authentication logs)
Contextual data about an account, which may include a username, user ID, environmental data, etc.
Changes made to an account, such as permissions and/or membership in specific groups (ex: Windows EID 4738 or /var/log access/authentication logs)
Information obtained (via shared or submitted samples) regarding malicious software (droppers, backdoors, etc.) used by adversaries

Code, strings, signatures, and other identifying characteristics of a malicious payload stored within a malware repository. It includes both static (file-based) and dynamic (behavioral or execution-based) components that can be analyzed for threat intelligence, detection, and prevention purposes.
Contextual data about a malicious payload, such as compilation times, file hashes, as well as watermarks or other identifiable configuration information
Credential material, such as session cookies or tokens, used to authenticate to web applications and services
Credential material, such as session cookies or tokens, used to authenticate to web applications and services
An attempt by a user to gain access to a network or computing resource by providing web credentials (ex: Windows EID 1202)
A single file used to deploy a virtual machine/bootable disk into an on-premise or third-party cloud environment
Initial construction of a virtual machine image (ex: Azure Compute Service Images PUT)
Removal of a virtual machine image (ex: Azure Compute Service Images DELETE)
Contextual data about a virtual machine image such as name, resource group, state, or type
Changes made to a virtual machine image, including setting and/or control data (ex: Azure Compute Service Images PATCH)

Verify the image hash of core NF or O-RAN applications (xApp/rApp) against known reference values for these hashes. Ensure the applications have the correct software patches installed. 
The hash could also be a 5G platform software image hash.
A computer program, at the core of a computer OS, that resides in memory and facilitates interactions between hardware and software components
An object file that contains code to extend the running kernel of an OS, typically used to add support for new hardware (as device drivers) and/or filesystems, or for adding system calls

Instances of computer programs that are being executed by at least one thread. Processes have memory space for process executables, loaded modules (DLLs or shared libraries), and allocated memory regions containing everything from user input to application-specific data structures
Operating system function/method calls executed by a process
Opening of a process by another process, typically to read memory of the target process (ex: Sysmon EID 10)
The initial construction of an executable managed by the OS, that may involve one or more tasks or threads. (e.g. Win EID 4688, Sysmon EID 1, cmd.exe > net use, etc.)
Contextual data about a running process, which may include information such as environment variables, image name, user/owner, etc.
Changes made to a process, or its contents, typically to write and/or execute code in the memory of the target process (ex: Sysmon EID 8)
Exit of a running process (ex: Sysmon EID 5 or Windows EID 4689)
Data object storage infrastructure hosted on-premise or by third-party providers, made available to users through network connections and/or APIs
Opening of a cloud storage infrastructure, typically to collect/read its value (ex: AWS S3 GetObject)
Initial construction of new cloud storage infrastructure (ex: AWS S3 CreateBucket)
Removal of cloud storage infrastructure (ex: AWS S3 DeleteBucket)
An extracted list of cloud storage infrastructure (ex: AWS S3 ListBuckets or ListObjects)
Contextual data about cloud storage infrastructure and activity around it such as name, size, or owner
Changes made to cloud storage infrastructure, including its settings and/or data (ex: AWS S3 PutObject or PutObjectAcl)
A file or stream containing a list of commands, allowing them to be launched in sequence
The execution of a text file that contains code via the interpreter (e.g. Powershell, WMI, Windows EID 4104, etc.)
Information from host telemetry providing insights about system status, errors, or other notable functional activity
Logging, messaging, and other artifacts highlighting the health of host sensors (ex: metrics, errors, and/or exceptions from logging applications)
A single unit of shared resources within a cluster, comprised of one or more containers
Initial construction of a new pod (ex: kubectl apply|run)
An extracted list of pods within a cluster (ex: kubectl get pods)
Changes made to a pod, including its settings and/or control data (ex: kubectl set|patch|edit)

Events collected by third-party services such as mail servers, web applications, or other appliances (not by the native OS or platform) Data sources with information about the set of devices found within the network, along with their current software and configurations
Logging, messaging, and other artifacts provided by third-party services (ex: metrics, errors, and/or alerts)
A non-volatile data storage device (hard drive, floppy disk, USB flash drive) with at least one formatted partition, typically mounted to the file system and/or assigned a drive letter

Refers to the act of accessing a data storage device, such as a hard drive, SSD, USB, or network-mounted drive. This data component logs the opening or mounting of drives, capturing activities such as reading, writing, or executing files within an assigned drive letter (e.g., C:\, /mnt/drive) or mount point.

The activity of assigning a new drive letter or creating a mount point for a data storage device, such as a USB, network share, or external hard drive, enabling access to its content on a host system.
The alteration of a drive letter, mount point, or other attributes of a data storage device, which could involve reassignment, renaming, permissions changes, or other modifications.
A directive given to a computer program, acting as an interpreter of some kind, in order to perform a specific task
The execution of a line of text, potentially with arguments, created from program code (e.g. a cmdlet executed via powershell.exe, interactive commands like >dir, shell executions, etc. )
A network security system, running locally on an endpoint or remotely as a service (ex: cloud environment), that monitors and controls incoming/outgoing network traffic based on predefined rules
Deactivation or stoppage of a cloud service (ex: Write/Delete entries within Azure Firewall Activity Logs)
An extracted list of available firewalls and/or their associated settings/rules
Contextual data about a firewall and activity around it such as name, policy, or status
Changes made to a firewall rule, typically to allow/block specific network traffic
A computer process that is configured to execute continuously in the background and perform system tasks, in some cases before any user has logged in
Initial construction of a new service/daemon (ex: Windows EID 4697 or /var/log daemon logs)
Contextual data about a service/daemon, which may include information such as name, service executable, start type, etc.
Changes made to a service/daemon, such as changes to name, description, and/or start type (ex: Windows EID 7040 or /var/log daemon logs)
A computer resource object, managed by the I/O system, for storing data (such as images, text, videos, computer programs, or any wide variety of other media).
Opening a file, which makes the file contents available to the requestor (ex: Windows EID 4663)
Initial construction of a new file (ex: Sysmon EID 11)
Removal of a file (ex: Sysmon EID 23, macOS ESF EID ES_EVENT_TYPE_AUTH_UNLINK, or Linux commands auditd unlink, rename, rmdir, unlinked, or renameat rules)
Contextual data about a file, which may include information such as name, the content (ex: signature, headers, or data/media), user/owner, permissions, etc.
File contents are changed by adversary.
Infrastructure, platforms, or software that are hosted on-premise or by third-party providers, made available to users through network connections and/or APIs
Deactivation or stoppage of a cloud service (ex: AWS Cloudtrail StopLogging)
An extracted list of cloud services (ex: AWS ECS ListServices)
Contextual data about a cloud service and activity around it such as name, type, or purpose/function
Changes made to a cloud service, including its settings and/or data (ex: AWS CloudTrail DeleteTrail or DeleteConfigRule)
A database and set of services that allows administrators to manage permissions, access to network resources, and stored data objects (user, group, application, or devices)
Requests for authentication credentials via Kerberos or other methods like NTLM and LDAP queries.
Object access refers to activities where AD objects (e.g., user accounts, groups, policies) are accessed or queried.
Creating new objects in AD, such as user accounts, groups, organizational units (OUs), or trust relationships. Logged as Event ID 5137
Object deletion in AD (e.g., user accounts, groups, OUs) is logged as Event ID 5141
Changes to AD objects (e.g., users, groups, OUs) are logged as Event ID 5136 (Object Modification) or 5163 (Attribute Changes).
Logon occurring on a system or resource (local, domain, or cloud) to which a user/device is gaining access after successful authentication and authorizaton
Initial construction of a successful new user logon following an authentication attempt. (e.g. Windows EID 4624, /var/log/utmp, or /var/log/wmtp)
Contextual data about a logon session, such as username, logon type, access tokens (security context, user SIDs, logon identifiers, and logon SID), and any activity associated within it
Data transmitted across a network (ex: Web, DNS, Mail, File, etc.), that is either summarized (ex: Netflow) and/or captured as raw data in an analyzable format (ex: PCAP)
Initial construction of a network connection, such as capturing socket information with a source/destination IP and port(s) (ex: Windows EID 5156, Sysmon EID 3, or Zeek conn.log)
Logged network traffic data showing both protocol header and body values (ex: PCAP)
Summarized network packet data, with metrics, such as protocol headers and volume (ex: Netflow or Zeek http.log)
A standard unit of virtualized software that packages up code and all its dependencies so the application runs quickly and reliably from one computing environment to another
Initial construction of a new container (ex: docker create )
An extracted list of containers (ex: docker ps)
Activation or invocation of a container (ex: docker start or docker restart)
Block object storage hosted on-premise or by third-party providers, typically made available to resources as virtualized hard drives
Initial construction of a cloud volume (ex: AWS create-volume)
Removal of a a cloud volume (ex: AWS delete-volume)
An extracted list of available volumes within a cloud environment (ex: AWS describe-volumes)
Contextual data about a cloud volume and activity around it, such as id, type, state, and size
Changes made to a cloud volume, including its settings and control data (ex: AWS modify-volume)
Information obtained (commonly via active network traffic probes or web crawling) regarding various types of resources and servers connected to the public Internet
Logged network traffic in response to a scan showing both protocol header and body values
Contextual data about an Internet-facing resource gathered from a scan, such as running services or ports
A digital document, which highlights information such as the owner's identity, used to instill trust in public keys used while encrypting network communications
Verify and refresh frequently digital signatures used for authenticating xApps by near-RT RIC and E2 nodes.
Data sources with information about the set of devices found within the network, along with their current software and configurations
This includes sources of current and expected devices on the network, including the manufacturer, model, and necessary identifiers (e.g., IP and hardware addresses)

This includes sources of current and expected software or application programs deployed to a device, along with information on the version and patch level for vendor products, full source code for any application programs, and unique identifiers (e.g., hashes, signatures).
Operational databases contain information about the status of the operational process and associated devices, including any measurements, events, history, or alarms that have occurred
This includes alarms associated with unexpected device functions, such as shutdowns, restarts, failures, or configuration changes
This includes any data stores that maintain historical or real-time events and telemetry recorded from various sensors or devices
This includes a list of any process alarms or alerts produced to indicate unusual or concerning activity within the operational process (e.g., increased temperature/pressure)
Visual activity on the device that could alert the user to potentially malicious behavior.
System prompts triggered when an application requests new or additional permissions
Notifications generated by the OS
Settings visible to the user on the device
RF spectrum contains information that can be used for signal direction finding and geolocation, as well as to detect jamming
Signal measurements to identify the presence of jamming source.
Radio layer messages between UE and the serving gNB (phy/MAC layer)
UE signals sent to gNB such as: measurements of received power levels from all base stations nearby, other signals such as Sounding Reference Signal (SRS).
gNB signals & messages broadcast for all UEs to hear- e.g. MIBs and SIBs, also PRS (Positioning Ref Signal)
Paging channel content

Data Source Name: NAS messages between UE and AMF
Description: NAS messages from UE to gNB or gNB to UE (e.g., NAS attach messages  for encryption/integrity algorithm downgrading to NULL, or NAS registration rejects for downgrade by network to steer UE to 4G/3G.)
Charging system records for anomaly detection
Content of Subscriber CDRs (Charging Data Records) (e.g., in Charging Funciton (CHF) logs)
SIM card usage logs in the network to identify any fraudulent use of SIM cards.

Data Source Name: Core logs for SIM usage pattern
Description: SIM card usage logs in the network to identify if more than one UE is using the same IMSI/SUPI simultaneously or the same IMSI/SUPI is being used in two impossible geographical locations within a short period of time. E.g. if the IMSI/SUPI is used in two locations which are far apart within a short period of time (not simultaneously).
Logs of battery, CPU, storage consumption and use
Unexpected power consumption or unexplained battery drain
Logs of access to operator O&M resources like IR.21, EIR databases.

Data Source Name: MNO database access logs  content in core
Description: Logs of all types of operator database access requests.

UE logs about RAT transition events, and user actions such as turn on or off airplane mode, SIM card operations. The logs can be collected using MDM/EMM from the operator.

(MDM=Mobile Device Management, EMM=Enterprise mobile management.)

Data Source Name: UE logs for radio network transition events
Description: UE modem logs  RAT transition events e.g. 5G to 4G or 3G.
UE service related logs from the Android or iOS applications in the application processor. These logs capture user actions such as turning on or off airplane mode.

Data Source Name: UE logs for SIM card accesses
Description: Messages between modem processor and SIM/eSIM.

Data Source Name: MNO logs in core for subscriber service complaints
Description: Subscriber complaints to the operator about issues they experience with connectivity, network performance or billing.

Data Source Name: MNO logs for service issues in core
Description: Subscriber complaint logs about degraded or denied service.
Security Incident and event monitoring. Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events should be produced, kept and regularly reviewed
Logs for security, authentication and authorization, host access (physical and virtual) etc.

Data Source Name: SDN Access Logs in SDN elements
Description: SDN logs to detect unauthorized activity

Data Source Name: SDN Access Logs in SDN elements
Description: Logs accessing SDN elements (routers, switches, SDN controllers)

Data Source Name: Packet capture for user plane packets
Description: Packets received at the User Plane Function (UPF)
Message payload of all user plane packets received from the internet at UPF or PGW for detecting encapsulated GTP-U packet.
Logs collected at the gNB or a 5G core network function.

Data Source Name: gNB log content for NULL encryption use
Description: gNB logs for NULL scheme usage in registration messages from UEs.

Data Source Name: Core network log content for NULL encryption use
Description: Core network logs for NULL scheme usage in registration messages from UEs.

Data Source Name: gNB log content for flooding of messages from UE
Description: Access request messages received from UEs (or a single UE) at the gNB within a short period of time.

Data Source Name: Core network log content for flooding of messages from UE
Description: Registration request messages received from UEs (or a single UE) at the core network within a short period of time.
gNB logs of UE experiencing frequent dropped connections, difficulty connecting and throttled data.
gNB logs for unplanned service outage.
Provisioning logs for UE related security configuration changes in core allowing NULL encryption of the SUPI.
gNB logs for replayed messages sent to gNB
UE operational logs in core NFs.
Core logs related to UE operations for events such as - UE makes an emergency call or in NSA mode, when a UE is ordered to connect to network via eNB.
Security related configuration logs in gNB and core.
Security related configuration logs in O-CU, O-DU and O-RU.
Security related configuration logs in core NFs.
Automated policy compliance checks

Data Source Name: User and resource policy configuration logs in core network
Description: User and resource policy configuration logs in core network for compliance violations.
UE application for detection of silent SMS messages.

Data Source Name: Silent SMS detector at UE side
Description: Logs in UE for detecting silent SMS messages.
Contents of the UE registration message in UDM/SIDF for SUCI parameter

Data Source Name: SUCI parameter for elliptic curve in UDM
Description: Registration message contents in UDM/SIDF for Ellitpic curve of public key sent by the UE.
Core performance counters for default and dedicated slices (bearers)

Data Source Name: Slice performance counters and KPIs of core NFs in MANO
Description: Network slice related performance management counters and KPIs of core NFs in MANO.
Inspection of hardware components
Manually inspect all hardware components for tampering.
Sensors on physical components
Facility intrusion detection and alert
Cabinet and cage instrusion detection and alert
Device instrusion detection and alert
Host system information on malicious software and configurations.
Reports of host system scans for malicious software and configurations.
